title: Multi Tool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Deutsch:
Die ist ein erweiterbarer Werkzeughalter. Basierend auf eine oder mehrere Grundplatten (100x100mm), die mit verschiedenen Werkzeug Haltern verschraubt werden können. Somit ist eine Problemlose Erweiterung möglich falls neues oder zusätzliches Werkzeug benötigt wird. Zu den verschiedenen Werkzeughalter benötigt man immer zusätzlich noch einen Grundständer. Insgesamt gibt es aktuell 6 verschiedene Gründständer (Base Stands), diese unterscheiden sich jeweils in 3 unterschiedlichen Breiten und in 2 unterschiedlichen Höhen. 46mm Höhe wenn der Werkzeughalter nur aus einem Teil besteht, und 42mm Höhe wenn er aus zwei Teilen besteht.
Englisch translation will follow later! Sorry :-)

description.text:
this is a smaller than normal gear for 3mm metal ball chain designed for more precission with adafruit motorshield v1 in my polargraph project.

"63mm per rev" in controller config

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cTgKrn9XfMW

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm head

Notes:

disable support

This is a 6.5 gram frame specially designed for hubsan x4 h107L but it would work just as well for any other micro quad with 7mm or 8.5mm motors. This frame was built to be sturdy yet lightweight (less than half the original frame's weight). This design is optimized for PLA printing but the mesh is fairly clean so feel free to post remakes for other materials for example, or just general improvements would be very much appreciated!

It has roughly the same dimensions as a hubsan x4 and the main plate reaches 3mm in thickness.

description.text:
This model can be used to make a cheap brushless gimbal for under 50 bucks!

This brushless gimbal can be used:

http://www.banggood.com/FPV-2-Axis-Brushless-Gimbal-With-Controller-For-DJI-Phantom-GoPro-3-p-908068.html

and this battery fits in the housing:

http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__32553__Turnigy_nano_tech_1300mah_3S_25_50C_Lipo_Pack_EU_Warehouse_.html?strSearch=lipo%203s

There is room for a switch or/and battery checker.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

0%

Notes:

The housing can be printed in upright position without support material.

This model needs some M3 screws and spacers.

If the Hole for the brushless motor is to narrow, a bit sanding to widen the hole is required.

A xt60 or balance plug can be used to connect to 3s LiPo.

the little hole in the side can be used to house a ON/OFF switch.
I designed it using SolidWorks,

description.text:
L - Frame Stabilizer. Adjustable stabilizer for prusa i3 single standard frame ( 6 mm/10 mm of thickness).
I designed this structure to reduce vibrations reinforceing the back side of printer adding an aluminium L profile. This solution is applicable to all prusa i3 printers with single standard frame of 6 mm/10 mm of thickness (for me 6 mm aluminium frame).

About 1 x 280 mm aluminium L profile ( section 30 X 20 x 2 mm ) - 1 m about 4-6 euro.
About 2 x 400 mm M8 thread - 1 m about 2-3 euro.

4 x M5 nuts and screws ( 20 mm ).
8 X M8 nuts.
4 x M3 nuts and screws ( 10 mm ) or 4 x self tapping screws.
4 x self tapping screws.
2 x M10 washer.

Washers, a drill and an hacksaw and some keys.

Instruction:
See instructions pictures. It is only required to unscrews two nuts of the printer (the M10 nuts of back side), mount the structure and screw.
Screw the M8 knob by hands !

title: Dual Auto Leveling Prusa i3 Reworked X-Idler Tensioner with T8 Leadscrew

description.text:
These parts are drop-in replacements for the Prusa i3 Reworked X-axis assembly and is meant to be used with the Herringbone Prusa i3 Reworked Greg's Extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1446842) The following changes were made to the original parts:

X-IDLER

1) A belt tensioner was added that can be used with either a 4x40mm bolt or a 5x40mm bolt. A nested nut trap is used to catch the smaller 4mm nut.The tensioner has an effective range of 11mm. An access port has been added to the side of the x-idler body in order to access the nut trap during installation or in the event that the nut trap becomes rounded. The tensioner has been designed around the 608ZZ bearing and is meant to be used with the included bearing guide. There is a 0.75mm clearance between the edge of the bearing guide and the tensioner body to prevent the belt from slipping off.

2) The inner diameter of the 8mm smooth rod holes was reduced in order to make it more difficult for the rods to slip. The ends of these holes were also closed up in order to keep the rods from slipping out the back.

3) The Z-axis nut trap was removed and replaced with a platform to catch a floating Z-axis switch. This is a design change similar to Crota's March 17 2014 design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:273805). However, this design's implementation of Crota's part more closely mirrors the technique used on the Robo 3D R1 printer. The Marlin firmware needs to be modified as explained by Crota to use this feature.

4) Multiple versions of the floating Z-axis platform are included in order to make this part compatible with printers using 5mm threaded rods, 8mm threaded rods, and T8 leadscrews.

X-MOTOR-END

1) Similar to the X-Idler above, the Z-axis nut trap was removed and replaced with a platform to catch a floating Z-axis switch. Having dual limit switches (on both ends of the X-axis assembly) eliminates the possibility of the nozzle being driven hard into the print bed in the event that one axis is lower than the other. This arrangement also allows for separate measurements to be taken on both sides of the print bed in order to calculate the the exact orientation of the printing surface relative to the nozzle for all points on the print bed.

2) Similar to the X-Idler above, multiple versions of the floating Z-axis platform are included in order to make this part compatible with printers using 5mm threaded rods, 8mm threaded rods, and T8 leadscrews.

Inspirition for modification

I was extremely impressed by the way the Robo 3D R1 managed auto-leveling of the bed. The Robo 3D attaches the Z-axis limiting switch to the X-axis mounts so that the switch 'floats' just under the X-axis. The switch is triggered when the Z-axis lowers enough for the nozzle to rest on the build plate. In this case, the limit switch is an OMRON 5E4 T85 (http://www.mouser.com/ds/2/307/SS_1110-14757.pdf). When the print nozzle is not touching the print bed, then the limit switch button is being pressed down by the weight of the X-axis and the switch does not send a signal to the Ramps board because it is in the open position. Terminals 1 and 3 of the limit switch are wired to the Ramps board and are wired as an open circuit when the button is pressed down. When the nozzle is touching the bed then the switch is up and the circuit is closed across terminals 1 and 3. This causes the Ramps board to register a z-axis trigger event.

Using the Robo 3D as a reference design, the existing Prusa i3 Reworked X-axis idler was modified to accommodate a 'floating' or 'following' Z-axis limit switch that hooks the X-axis idler body.

The Prusa i3 Reworked modified X-idler with floating Z-axis limit switch. The Robo 3D X-Motor-End with floating Z-axis limit switch. Side on view of Z-axis switch hooking into the X-idler body. A top view of the Robo 3D's Z-axis hook. The mount plate can be switched to hold a nut for 8mm and 5mm threaded rods or to hold a T8 leadscrew nut.

author: Godvalve

description.text:
I have this HUGE NVidia 770 gtx that was constantly leaning in my case.
I don't like when things are not straight, so I designed an adjustable bracket to keep it horizontal.
The bracket makes contact with the gpu shroud between the two fans and its secured in place using 3 screws on the pci expansion ports.
You can use the default thumbscrews that came in with the case, but you have to leave the ports behind the case open, or you can change the thumbscrews with normal screws and keep everything closed.

Doesn't Matter

the higher, the tougher

Notes:

I printed this with a 40% infill in clear blue pla from Ultimaker. Even when I play the gpu does not go hotter than 60°C, also the bracket makes contact with the gpu on the fan shroud, which is always cool, so I've had no deformations at all.
Feel free to experiment with the materials and make sure that the bracket doesn't block any fan.
Feel also free to modify my design to accomodate your case/gpu

title: Sony HDR-AS20 Action cam open mount

description.text:
A quick mount for the Sony action cam HDR-AS20 (and compatible models, such as HDR-AS15). The distinguishing feature about this mount is that it leaves the latch that covers the charging port and microphone port still accessible.

It also provides a small GoPro-compatible mount to be used with GoPro accessories. Otherwise design a 16mm wide, flat piece and glue it on top of the mount to join it with anything of your choice.

Prints in three pieces and they are glued together with super glue.

Printer Brand:

CEL

Printer:

Robox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal, 0.2mm

Infill:

70%

Gluing

Just simply glue the smallest piece onto the long rod that goes along the length of the camera. It locks the camera in place in the mount.

Then glue the GoPro mount on top in a location that is balanced with regards to the center of gravity of the mount + camera.

Done!

description.text:
This is an adaptor for 3 mL syringes so that they can be used on the paste extruder designed for 10 mL syringes by Shapescribe. (The extruder can be viewed here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:591849)

The adaptor fixes 3 mL syringes inside the hole of the extruder to prevent swaying motion. The piston stopper ensures firm contact between the pressure block and the end of the syringe piston.

The syringe should be inserted into the adaptor (3mL Syringe Adaptor.stl), and the piston stopper (Piston Stopper.stl) should be put onto the end of the syringe piston. Then the assembly is ready for use as a normal 10 mL syringe on the extruder.

title: front support for foldable shoulder rig
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A front-support

Use a leg of one of these super-cheap tripods:
http://www.dealextreme.com/p/professional-portable-retractable-tripod-for-slr-digital-camera-65324?r=78675737 Add an M5x25 bolt and a wing-nut (or a wing-bolt and a nut) as an axis. Then mount everything through the front-hole in the rig with an M5x10 bolt and a large washer.
The hole for the bolt is tapered for easy insertion as the bolt will have to gut it's own thread to be mounted securely without a nut. Sewing a small pocket for a belt is trivial and I won't go into much detail there.
Just get a piece of wide belt 3x as long as your belt is wide and fold it up into 3 layers.

comments.text: How do you gut threads?

comments.text: ABs and PLA are both soft enough, so you can just screw in the bolt and it will hold very fast.

title: Simple extruder filament guide for eMAKER Huxley

description.text: The filament tends to slip out of the hobbed area of the extruder drive bolt on my machine. I wanted to make a new extruder block, either http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13530 or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14317 but of course, because my extruder couldn't be left unattended for more than a minute or two, and this is a big part, I couldn't ever get one finished. So this is just a little insert that sits inside the extruder chamber, and prevents the filament from being squeezed out. It's dead simple.

comments.text:
Thank you. Thank you. Thank you!
After a mounting pile of failed prints on my Huxley I took a punt on a vague memory and typed "Huxley filament guide" into Thingiverse.
I had been getting suspicious that my extruder jams were being caused by sideways slipping of the filament when I found relatively little plastic in the hobbed bolt teeth and some patches on the extruded filament with no apparent toothmarks.
I managed to print one of these little beauties and immediately managed a tall 3 hour print with no problems.
comments.author: richgain

comments.text: I shall be trying this myself as well, I am getting fed up setting the extruder to do 400mm to start the filament and then ending up taking so long getting the filiment to bite it goes in by about 50mm! lol Love the simple thought for this  :)
comments.author: smartroad

comments.text: Haven't had a single problem with the feed since putting this in - and it's small enough to print even with a badly behaved extruder - hay presto!
comments.author: smartroad

comments.text: Interesting. I was having the same problem with my Huxley. The filament has to come in perpendicular to the extruder face or it'll pop off to the side. I'll have to try this.
comments.author: JamesRPatrick

My first set of badges that I designed for use with the Artemis Spaceship Bridge Simulator game. (( http://artemis.eochu.com/ )) These badges designate the station that you are playing as. Similar to the Startrek Communicator logo from the Next generation and beyond. These badges were designed in Blender and are intended to be used with a magnetic clasp so that damage to cosplay or uniform or T-Shirts is minimal. It was my intent to glue the metal bar to the back of the badge and use th magnets behind the clothing to afix it to the person.

Artemis already has their own "patches" for each station. I wanted something custom and unique.

This is a work in progress that is likely to see a few updates. If you have suggestion please message them to me. if you want to edit the files please use the attached .blend file.

comments.text: These look fantastic and are just the sort of thing I was looking for. I hope to make a few of these to both give to people after they have played as a station for a full session, as well as use them for a random assignment bag people pull a token from.

So, I broke the arm of my toilet paper holder and decided to print a new one.
And then as an exercise I went a bit further and drew the whole thing and made it customizable.

With default settings it resembles the one I used as a model, but the locking mechanism as well as certain other things had to be changed due to reasons.

This was actually pretty difficult design, but surprisingly not because of all the round edges, but the OpenScad kept exporting invalid and broken STL files, but finally I found a way to design it so that the exported files are ok.

It is possible to make a non-working design in customizer so keep that in mind.
Tell me if there's something I didn't think of.

You may have to take a knife and carve the edges out of the arm, from the part which goes into the holder (last image), especially if your first layer is wide and fat. Don't force it in too hard, you're only going to split the holder.

Anyway, it would probably be faster and maybe even cheaper to go and buy one instead of printing one. I made this just as an exercise after all.

Tue Mar 29 23:00 2016 (GMT) Edit: I made a small edit to how the holder's placement is calculated, but it should only affect when the arm is very short compared to the holder or the arm's corner diameter is larger than 10. Hopefully I didn't break anything.

Ever needed an excuse to start building Lego again? Now is the time! Turns out Lego bricks can be used to build a perfect symmetrical frame for your quadcopter! And... it's super cheap.

I used Lego Technic because it has holes in the bricks. You can mount the motor's with tie wraps through the holes and it's an ideal weight reduction. For the motor's and flight controller I used parts from the famous Hubsan X4.

http://www.banggood.com/buy/hubsan-x4.html?p=KX28152008068201507H

Step 1: Parts / Materials

You'll need the following tools/materials:

Lego (of course)
Soldering iron
Elastic band
Soldering tin for electric components (optional)
Doublesided tape (optional)
I ordered my Hubsan X4 parts from http://www.banggood.com/buy/Hubsan-x4.html?p=KX28152008068201507H They have the parts even cheaper then ebay. This is what you need:

Hubsan flight controler 107l or 107c (107l if your planning on adding fancy led lights, 107c if your planning on adding a camera)
4 7mm hollow cup motors
4 blades (and maybe some spare)
3.7v battery + charger
Hubsan remote (if you dont have one)
If you don't have a remote yet, then it's probably cheaper to buy a rtf hubsan x4. You can take it apart and as a bonus you get the original hubsan x4 frame!

Step 2: Soldering the flight controler

Step 2: Soldering the flight controler
This requires a little soldering but nothing really hard. If you look at the flight controller, the place where you need to solder the motor's is already labeled.

And as you've probably seen there are clockwise and counterclockwise motor's. It important to place the same motor's opposite of each otter. So clockwise motor opposite of the other clockwise motor and same for counterclockwise.

The flight controller already has some soldering tin on it, but it's not much. So you can add some extra if you want.

Step 3: Building your Lego frame

Step 3: Building your Lego frame

I will let the pictures do the talking. You don't have to build exactly the same frame I build. With a little imagination you can build some awesome frames! Just don't make the frame to heavy or it will be very hard to fly (if it even has lift off). Please share you awesome frames for inspiration!

Step 4: Mounting the motor's and flight controller

Step 4: Mounting the motor's and flight controller

What I mentioned earlier is that Lego Technic is perfect for mounting the props. It has holes in the bricks and all you need to do is mount the motor's with tie wraps trough the holes. I also used double sided tape to keep the motor's in place. Fixate the flight controller on top, battery under the frame and your good to go!

Let me know if you have questions, I'll be happy to answer them. Good luck building your own Legocopter!

description.text: What is a rekenrek, you ask? It's kind of like a simplified abacus used for arithmetic and number sense in the primary grades, of course! Print some out and make them available to the elementary math students in your life and watch their addition, subtraction, and number composition skills soar! Or just listen to them slide the counting rings back and forth until it drives you batty, either way.

MakerBot

title: F450/Q450 Flame Wheel Quadcopter Top Cage

description.text:
NEW NOTE June 17, 2016: the STL models are in Millimeters, so it may show up very tiny when you import it into your slicer. I forgot about this because I use Makerware, which automatically recognizes this issue and prompts you to scale it up. One inch = 25.4 millimeters, so if you import it into your slicer and it is super tiny, you can resize it from mm to inches by uniformly scaling it (that is, scaling it in all directions, X, Y and Z) by 2540%.

Simple top cage for DJI Flame Wheel 450 quadcopter (or imitations). Protects electronics and provides a convenient mounting point for FPV antenna. Also makes a good place to secure wires for strain relief.

Instructions:
Print Part1 and Part2. Snap two parts together at 90 degrees as shown in the photo. Attach to quadcopter arms with zip ties. Note: the slots where the two parts connect at the top are intentionally tight to avoid vibration. You will probably need to slightly trim the insides of the slots by sanding or with a knife.

Print Settings:
It worked well for me at 40% fill with two shells.

If you like it, please click the "heart" button and leave a comment.

Thanks!

PS. The KK2.1 flight controller case you see in the pictures is the one posted on Thingiverse by "rcmanchild". Works great!

comments.text: Each part is showing up in Cura as being only 7mm long, makes for a very small cage.  Did you by any chance generate the .stl files in inches instead of millimeters?
comments.author: ChiefPoints

comments.text:
Hi there,
Oh very sorry. Yes, needs to be scaled from mm to inches. I use Makerbot Makerware and it automatically recognizes the size issue and prompts you to rescale it, so i have not bothered to figure out how to fix the stl files generated out of my CAD software. Hope you were able to make it work.

description.text:
Esse modelo é um exercício pessoal para o 1o Esquenta do Hackathon FIESP 2016, cujo tema é Movimento Maker e Internet das Coisas e do qual eu sou uma das organizadoras líderes.

Esse hackathon está entre os maiores e mais legais de toda a América Latina :)

O pato foi adaptado do modelo Rubber Duck Boat Multi-color
(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:155679) para se parecer com símbolo da campanha #NãoVouPagaroPato, criada e liderada pela FIESP.

This model was a personal exercise for the FIESP Hackathon 2016 - Maker Movement and IoT, which I am a lead organizer.

This rubber duck was adapted from the Rubber Duck Boat Multi-color (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:155679) to look like the rubber duck of the #NaoVouPagaroPato campaign against the high taxation policy in Brazil, created and led by FIESP (the Industry Federation of Sao Paulo State). The hashtag means "I won't carry the can", which in Brazilian Portuguese is stated literally as "I won't pay the duck".

Overtime, the Duckzilla on Paulista Avenue became an icon of the recent protests against the corruption scandals investigated by the Car Wash operation.

As of the hackathon, it is among the biggest and coolest hackthons in the region! :)

Timelapse video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AXM-GjF8Ts4

title: Difference Engine v2.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Babbage's Difference engine. Can calculate polynomials. Animation: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8X6iIpjawZU This is a revision of thing 7609, but is not compatible. This in incomplete. Parts Remaining
    • Carry Mechanism
    • Timing/Lift Mechanism
    • Detents for wheels (prevents unwanted rotation)
    • Thrust bearings

Not all parts exist yet
Parts that do not exist are in italics
Parts that exist are in Bold A machine with n columns can calculate polynomials of up to the (n-1)th degree. (3 columns to solve quadratic, 4 for cubic, etc.) Customizer Changes
    • Change the Tab Offset until Bottom Plates A and B fit tightly together.
    • Change the Sliding Tab Offsets until the tabs on Sector Wheel Bearing Plate loosely slide in the slots in Bottom Plate A.
    • Parts

  • Print/find two Lego Technic axles for for each column.
    Print one of each part for each column.
    Except
    Print two of Thrust Bearings for each column.
    Print one of ODD or EVEN parts for every odd or even column.

    • Assembly
    1. Press together all Bottom Plates, alternating A and B
    2. Press all Lift Plates 15mm onto Technic axles
    3. Insert Technic axles with Lift Plates into holes in Bottom Plate A. Lift Plates should be touching Bottom Plate A
    4. Insert remaining Technic Axles into Bottom Plate B
    5. Slide one Thrust Bearing onto each Plate A axle
    6. Slide Bearing Plates onto Plate A axles. The tabs on the Bearing Plates should go into the slots in Bottom Plate A
    7. Slide one Thrust Bearing onto each Plate A axle
    8. Press all Sector Wheel Tabs into Sector Wheels
    9. Slide Sector Wheels onto Plate A axles
    10. Slide Figure Wheels onto Plate B axles
    11. Press Sector Wheel Restore Arms onto Plate A axles
    12. Press Figure Wheel Restore Arms onto Plate B axles

title: makerbot 5th gen ninja flex guide for extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hey everyone i found this online ,
I attached the stl. for the makerbot smart extruder upgrade to allow you to work with ninja flex. It may take a few tries, but you will eventually get the hang of it. As mentioned in my previous post, I used the recommended settings from ninjaflex. Keep in my that by opening your smart extruder, you void the warranty.

Lift the wheel to facilitate installing the piece around the groove. It should fit snug opposite the circuit board. The tail will be above the magnet to prevent it from spinning.

This piece will prevent the ninjaflex from buckling by removing any gap that can be used by the filament to squeeze through.

Have fun printing!
http://animechats.com/2015/11/15/makerbot-5th-gen-printing-with-ninja-flex/

title: Motor mount for Brooklyn Aerodrome Towel RC plane

description.text: Prototype mount for a TowerPro brushless motor intended for Brooklyn Aerodrome's Towel RC plane design.

Build instructions for the Towel are available on the Brooklyn Aerodrome site:
http://brooklynaerodrome.com/build1.html This part is a drop-in replacement for the motor mount described in the above instructions. The dxf file has a drawing of the TowerPro plate for which the mount was originally designed. Change the dims there for alternate plates and recompile the OpenSCAD model. Additionally, there is a "margin" parameter in the scad file if the plate is just a bit tight. You'll have to drill out the bolt holes on the mount face for the plate; the set screw locations were different relative to the mounting holes for each of the four motors I have, and I wanted them to be in an accessible location once the mount was attached to the Towel deck.

This SD card holder fits into the Express Card slot in your notebook computer. Holds 2 standard SD cards and 2 micro-SD cards.

I attached freecad parametric file for anyone to tweak with it.

print_settings.Notes:: I used an infill of 20% to make the pieces slightly stronger than normal.

description.text:
This is a set of cylindrical sections to form the barrel of Boba Fett's EE-3 blaster (Empire Strikes Back version). The sections are designed to be printed and slide over a piece of PVC 40mm waste pipe. They could be glued together and form the barrel on their own but the pipe makes the assembly much stronger. The photos show my blaster in its current state. I used polyfilla to smooth the joins between the barrel sections.

I used black 40mm waste pipe because it was easy to obtain. A standard pipe coupler is then used to bulk out one end. As such my barrel is an approximation and not 100% screen accurate.

Barrel
The barrel set is made up of four sections to make printing easier.

The total barrel length is 205mm with the pieces in this order :
30mm + 50mm + 35mm + 90mm.

The 35mm and 50mm pieces have sections missing to form the characteristic "L" shape on the barrel.

I've included a 45mm section so you print two of those instead of the 90mm section. It was easier for me to print two of these rather than the 90mm piece.

The inner diameter is 42mm. I would recommend printing 10mm of one piece and aborting so you can test the fit. This will give you a chance to scale the print before before committing to a full set.

End Nozzle
The nozzle slides inside the pipe. It has two holes on the side. This allows you to pin or screw the nozzle in place. In my blaster there is a length of wood running the entire length so I inserted two small screws through the pipe, through the nozzle holes and into the wood. With a bit of epoxy glue the nozzle is firmly in place.

Side Fins
The side fins are attached by drilling four 5mm holes in the pipe coupler. The pegs on the fins can then be glued in place.

I will update the photos when I've made more progress.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Fisher

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used an infill of 20% to make the pieces slightly stronger than normal.

After printing I slide onto the 40mm waste pipe and secured with two-part epoxy. I filled some of the gap with super glue just to make sure. Once all the sections were in place I filled with Polyfilla and sanded.

These items were designed in FreeCAD.

Extruded 12 sided polygon to form the body
Radial array of padded sketches to form the fins
Cylinder to punch out the centre

A simple stand for the white plastic unibody MacBook.  
Make sure to rotate it, something weird happens when I export the STL file.

Printed with:
  • 0.25mm Layer height
  • 25% Infill
  • 1mm Wall thickness
  • 1mm Bottom/Top thickness

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40703

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=40703

Using the following options:

iphone_version = 1

build_plate_selector = 0
pattern_overlap = 100
pattern_shape = 6
pattern_radius = 4

This project started out as a small upgrade to a kit 3D printer I bought but ended up as a complete printer. It is designed around a frame of M10 threaded rods for stability, which is where the name come from as well. All plastic parts are printable and are made to be sturdy for stability. The weakest link I found in the kit printer I started out with was that many printed parts where mounted together to form a bigger part. I tried to avoid this by making the parts as big as necessary and only mounting hardware like rods and bearing blocks. This will of course mean more material is needed and the total weight of the printed parts is around 900 grams. The X-carriage was designed to fit a Greg's Wade reloaded or my remix of Minimalistic Mk7 replacement
It's probably possible to use other extruders using the 50 mm hole distance as well. Some of the parts needed:
  • M10 threaded rods + nuts and washers
  • M8 threaded rods + nuts and washers
  • M6 threaded rods + nuts and washers
  • 8 mm Smooth rods
  • SC8UU bearing blocks
  • RepRap PCB Heatbed, I'm using this one
    • Note: Some parts might need to be rotated in order to print them. The frame blocks are designed to work with this [Heavy duty Vibration damper](http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:94279 ) I have made a 3D PDF of the printer available for download

2015-01-03: Some changes have been made since the last update. The biggest are:
  • New heatbed: Helios Heat Bed kit
  • New extruder: Bulldog XL Extruder
  • Changed Z-axis threaded rods to trapezoidal lead screw
  • Adjustable belt tensioner for the X-axis
    All these changes has made the printer better and more importantly it seems like it's more reliable. All the new files are available on the Github page.
    • 2014-05-30: The Y-axis is now modified to use 8 mm smooth rods so that those are the only rods used for the whole printer and SC8UU are used everywhere. I also modifided the design of the Y-motor mount to be able to print it flat (prints faster) and tried to make it more robust. I recommend printing the Y-motor mount at 100% infill. The new parts are:
  • Y Motor Mount Rev 2
  • Y Smooth Rod Ends - Rev 2.1
  • Y Belt Holder Rev 2
    • 2014-05-13: The Marlin configuration I'm using with the RAMPS controller is available on Github. I've also moved old compenent no longer used on the newest version of RodBot to an archive folder here. 2014-05-12: Modified the Y ends to have a easier and more robust clamp for the belt. It is now easier to adjust the tension as it's just a matter of turning to screws. This also removes the problem I had with the plastic holding the belt cracking. The new parts are:
  • Y Smooth Rod Ends - Rev 2
  • Y Belt Holder
    Hardware needed:
  • 2 pcs M3x25mm or longer
  • 2 pcs M3x16mm
  • 4 pcs M3 Lock nut
  • 2 pcs M3 nut
  • 8 pcs M3 washer
    Some photos of the assembly: Photo 1, Photo 2, Photo 3.
    • 2014-05-08: All files are available on GitHub along with some development and some old files as well. 2014-04-30: I recently replaced my J-Head hotend with an E3D hotend but I needed to widen the x assembly by 5 mm in order to fit it. The new parts for the wider x-assembly are:
  • X Carriage Rev 3
  • X-End Idler Clamp Rev 2
  • X-End Idler Rev 2
  • X-End Motor Clamp Rev 2
  • X-End Motor Rev 2
    To secure the E3D Hotend I'm using this mount from dmarett. See the pictures I've taken for more details.
    • 2014-03-29: The fan mount I designed didn't work very well so I have now replaced it with this, which is a remix of this one but with a slightly modified mount to fit on the two screws for the belt holders.

comments.text: I'm sorry to see that there has been no traffic on this Thing's page here for well over a year, it looks like a fantastic machine.  I've been looking for something like it to replace my highly modified Printrbot Simple and this is similar to the design and implementation that I've been considering.  I love the open framework, utilization of threaded bar, and blocky, functional connectors... beautiful in its minimalization.

comments.text:
There's a lot of great printer designs out there so mine probably gets lost there somewhere, but thanks for your kind words.
Regarding your question, I haven't had any troubles with the z-axis motors. I'm using regular NEMA17 with a DRV8825 driver board. Considering the z-axis only moves on layer changes they don't have to work that hard. Prusa i3 has the same setup and many other printers as well.

comments.author: jledwards666

comments.text: I did see the PDF, thnx.  I will check the github material as well.
comments.author: sandberg

comments.text:
I'm using an arduino mega with a ramps shield running marlin. Basically the most standard reprap electronics you can get and it does the job quite well.
The version of marlin I'm currently running is also on my github page: https://github.com/hampussandberg/RodBot-Marlin-Ramps
comments.author: jledwards666

comments.text: I'm guessing your first name is Hampus?  That's unusual to a Californian like me.  Where are you from?
comments.author: sandberg

comments.text: Ah, I see from your profile that you're in Sweden, awesome.  I think that's where the book "The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo" was set, eh?
comments.author: jledwards666

comments.text: I also see that you state you're using the Bulldog extruder now.  $149, ouch!
comments.author: jledwards666

comments.text:
The extruder I used before with the funky gear is this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18379
I bought a bulldog extruder after a while to see if it was any good and I'm glad I did as it's ridiculously strong. With the wade extruder it would sometime slip but with the bulldog I have never had any problem, so it's worth the money!
comments.author: jledwards666

comments.text:
Latest updates looks good and the photos are great. I could see every details.
I would loop the y belt the other way around so it would have more contact with the gear teeth.
comments.author: 3Dexpression

comments.text: As you can see there are two holes for the idler which are symmetric in regards to the motor so you should be able to loop it the other way around and get the N you were talking about.
comments.author: 3Dexpression

comments.text: Thanks Sandberg for the reply. Yea glad you like the E3D. Most of us using it would rate it at about 30% improvement in print quality over the hotends we were using. Yes, you are right about my request on the minimalistic direct drive extruder. The trick is to have a strong spring to press the fila against the gear almost to the extend that it stalls the motor. So far all of us here that I know dont go back to the geared extruder after we go direct and we have also switched  the 1.75mm fila.
comments.author: 3Dexpression

comments.text:
Hi Sandberg, Nice update there with the E3D. I was hesistant to upgrade the x carriage cause I was using the E3D.
You can make a MK8 hobbed bolt version for your minimalistic extruder.
comments.author: 3Dexpression

comments.text:
Thanks Mike! The E3D seems like a really nice hotend and so far the prints look great with it. Regarding the minimalistic extruder I've actually had major problem getting any direct drive extruder to work as good as the Wade geared extruder I'm using at the moment. Maybe I will give it a new try with this new hotend.
Do you mean with the question if I can redesign the remix I made to fit a MK8 drive gear?
comments.author: 3Dexpression

comments.text:
Thanks Sandberg for the reply. Yea glad you like the E3D. Most of us using it would rate it at about 30% improvement in print quality over the hotends we were using. I am curious how you secure the E3D to the X carriage. Can add a photo?
Yes, you are right about my request on the minimalistic direct drive extruder. The trick is to have a strong spring to press the fila against the gear almost to the extend that it stalls the motor. So far all of us here that I know dont go back to the geared extruder after we go direct and we have also switched the 1.75mm fila.
comments.author: sandberg

comments.text:
I'm using this mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:220811http://www.thingiverse.com/thi..., I hope the pictures I took are detailed enough. It's the black part under the red Wade extruder. (The pictures are on the second image page)
The biggest problem with the direct extruder I had was that I tried to get it to work with 3mm filament which is probably way too hard. I still have like 10kg of 3mm filament left so I have to print all that first before switching to 1.75mm!
comments.author: 3Dexpression

comments.text: Thanks. Yes that mount looks good. Yea I thing the 3mm fila may have issues due to the amount of compression acting on it by the side.
comments.author: sandberg
